42. You should also renounce Minium and Spanish green,
And Orpiment, poisonous by nature.
I advise you to clean your Brushes well,
or keep some for clear blue Fabric
or Skies, and moreover, if you can do so,
be sure to provide yourself over time
with pure colors and learn to keep them ready,
as one who holds art in esteem and honors it.
right-middleAvoiding Minium, Spanish green, and Orpiment.

43. The smalts must be well absorbed.
To achieve this, some prick very dense holes
In their panels with needles.
Others cover their work with some rough paper,
which they leave there to draw out
the oil, and some others paint
with Poppyseed oil, while others
use Oil prepared according to their own experience.
right-middleSmalts must be absorbed, to discolor less.

ab.b: End of Painting well, or the Application of Colors.

33. Because many painters spatter their nudes
with white highlights, and are so wrong,
so that they would no longer do so,
there were some Writers who wished
that Lead-white were as expensive
as beautiful precious stones one seeks
in far countries, in costly mines,
or as pure Ultramarine.
right-middleTo avoid white highlights, one wished lead-white to be as expensive as Ultramarine

div.ab:
34. Now, to help understand the sense of highlights,
I will tell what Goltzius said,
that Titian (it is worth hearing)
had painted in a Nativity
a shepherd seen from the front, coming forward;
on his forehead, to make it stand out well,
there appeared only a single highlight
while the rest dissolved and vanished.

35. So the Italians are more inventive
in their use of color than we are. Whatever we do,
their figures are much plumper and softer
than ours; we also have the habit of enhancing light
right-middleNetherlanders are not well accomplished in coloring.
